answers.text: geographic scope of interests, actions, or projected power

qas.question: Who stated that "Great power may be defined as a political force exerting an effect co-extensive with the widest range of the society in which it operates. The Great powers of 1914 were 'world-powers"?
What type of powers should have actual influence throughout the scope of the prevailing international system?
What type of power is restricted to its region?

plausible_answers.text: a geographic scope of interests, actions, or projected power.

qas.question: What three things do all political forces have?
What should a Western society possess?
What is a range of society restricted to?
What were international systems called in 1914?
What political force was world-wide in 1914?

context: All states have <b4_0>a <a0_0>geographic scope of interests, actions, or projected power<a0_0/>.<b4_0/> This is a crucial factor in distinguishing a great power from a <a3_0>regional power<a3_0/>; by definition the scope of a regional power is restricted to <b6_0>its region<b6_0/>. It has been suggested that a <a2_0>great power<a2_0/> should be possessed of <b5_0>actual influence<b5_0/> throughout the scope of the prevailing international system. <a1_0>Arnold J. Toynbee<a1_0/>, for example, observes that "Great power may be defined as a political force exerting an effect co-extensive with the widest range of the society in which it operates. The Great powers of 1914 were '<b7_0>world-powers<b7_0/>' because <b8_0>Western<b8_0/> society had recently become 'world-wide'."
